% R1 (OS→Hamiltonian for loops)
% Self‑contained snippet; no external refs or packages.


\paragraph{Setup and axioms.}
Let $\mathfrak A$ be a unital $*$‑algebra generated by gauge‑invariant loop observables in Euclidean time. Let $\mathfrak A_+\subset\mathfrak A$ denote the $*$‑subalgebra of observables supported in the half‑space $\{t\ge 0\}$. We are given:
\begin{itemize}
\item[(RP)] (Reflection.) An anti\-linear involution $\theta:\mathfrak A\to\mathfrak A$ with $\theta^2=\mathrm{id}$, $\theta(ab)=\theta(b)\theta(a)$, and $\theta(a^*)=\theta(a)^*$, interchanging time halves: $\theta(\mathfrak A_+)=:\mathfrak A_-$.
\item[(TT)] (Time translations.) A $*$‑automorphism group $\{\tau_t\}_{t\in\mathbb R}$ of $\mathfrak A$ with $\tau_t(\mathfrak A_+)\subset\mathfrak A_+$ for $t\ge 0$ and $\theta\,\tau_t\,\theta=\tau_{-t}$. (Equivalently: the map is a semigroup on $\mathfrak A_+$ and extends to a group on $\mathfrak A$.)
\item[(S)] (State \& symmetries.) A normalized state $S:\mathfrak A\to\mathbb C$ with $S(1)=1$, $S(x^*x)\ge 0$, $S(a^*)=\overline{S(a)}$, invariant under reflection and time translations: $S(\theta(a))=S(a)$ and $S(\tau_t(a))=S(a)$.
\item[(OS)] (Osterwalder–Schrader positivity.) For every finite family $\{a_i\}\subset\mathfrak A_+$, the Gram matrix $\big[S(a_i^*\theta(a_j))\big]_{i,j}$ is positive semidefinite.
\item[(C)] (Continuity.) For each $a\in\mathfrak A_+$, $t\mapsto\tau_t(a)$ is continuous in the seminorm $\|a\|_{\mathrm{OS}}^2:=S(a^*\theta(a))$.
\end{itemize}
These are the standard OS hypotheses specialized to loop observables. No further structure of ``loops'' is used below.


\paragraph{Claim.}
There exist a Hilbert space $\mathcal H$, a cyclic vector $\Omega\in\mathcal H$, a $*$‑representation $\pi$ of the $*$‑algebra $\mathrm{alg}(\mathfrak A_+,\theta(\mathfrak A_+))$ on $\mathcal H$, and a strongly continuous self‑adjoint contraction semigroup
\[
U(t)=e^{-tH},\qquad t\ge 0,\quad H\ge 0\ \text{self‑adjoint},
\]
such that:
\begin{align}
&\text{(vacuum)}\qquad S(a)=\langle\Omega,\pi(a)\Omega\rangle,\ \ \forall a\in \mathrm{alg}(\mathfrak A_+,\theta(\mathfrak A_+)), \label{eq:vac}\\
&\text{(OS inner product)}\qquad \langle[a],[b]\rangle=S(a^*\theta(b)),\ \ \forall a,b\in\mathfrak A_+, \label{eq:OSip}\\
&\text{(covariance)}\qquad U(t)\,\pi(x)=\pi(\tau_t x)\,U(t),\ \ \forall x\in \mathrm{alg}(\mathfrak A_+,\theta(\mathfrak A_+)),\ t\ge 0. \label{eq:cov}
\end{align}
Moreover, letting $T:=U(1)=e^{-H}$ (the transfer operator), if $T$ has a spectral gap $\gamma>0$ away from the constant sector $\mathbb C\Omega$ in the sense that
\[
\mathrm{spec}\!\left(T\!\restriction_{\Omega^\perp}\right)\subset[0,e^{-\gamma}],
\]
then
\[
\mathrm{spec}(H)\cap(0,\gamma)=\varnothing.
\]


\paragraph{Proof.}
\emph{Step 1 (OS/GNS Hilbert space).} Define the null space
\[
\mathcal N:=\{a\in\mathfrak A_+\;:\;S(a^*\theta(a))=0\}.
\]
By (OS), the sesquilinear form $\langle a,b\rangle_{\mathrm{OS}}:=S(a^*\theta(b))$ on $\mathfrak A_+$ is positive semidefinite and anti\-linear in the first slot, linear in the second. Factor and complete:
\[
\mathcal H:=\overline{\mathfrak A_+/ \mathcal N}^{\ \langle\cdot,\cdot\rangle_{\mathrm{OS}}},\qquad [a]\in\mathcal H \text{ denotes the class of }a\in\mathfrak A_+.
\]
This is the OS/GNS space, and \eqref{eq:OSip} holds by construction.
Let $\Omega:=[1]$. For $a\in\mathfrak A_+$ define $\pi(a)[b]:=[ab]$. The product $ab$ lies in $\mathfrak A_+$, so $\pi(a)$ is well‑defined on $\mathfrak A_+/\mathcal N$ and extends by continuity to a bounded operator on $\mathcal H$ (boundedness is not needed later). Cyclicity is immediate: $\mathrm{span}\,\pi(\mathfrak A_+)\Omega$ contains $[a]$ for every $a\in\mathfrak A_+$.


\emph{Step 2 (reflection and extension of $\pi$).} Define an antiunitary involution $J$ on $\mathcal H$ by
\[
J[a]=[\theta(a^*)],\qquad J^2=1,\qquad \langle J\xi,J\eta\rangle=\langle\eta,\xi\rangle.
\]
The compatibility $\theta(ab)=\theta(b)\theta(a)$ and $\theta(a^*)=\theta(a)^*$ make $J$ well‑defined on the quotient. Extend $\pi$ to the $*$‑algebra generated by $\mathfrak A_+$ and $\theta(\mathfrak A_+)$ by
\[
\pi(\theta(a)):=J\,\pi(a^*)\,J,\qquad a\in\mathfrak A_+.
\]
Then $\pi$ is a $*$‑representation on $\mathcal H$:
$\pi(xy)=\pi(x)\pi(y)$ and $\pi(x)^*=\pi(x^*)$ for all $x,y$ in $\mathrm{alg}(\mathfrak A_+,\theta(\mathfrak A_+))$.


\emph{Step 3 (vacuum expectation).} For $a\in\mathfrak A_+$,
\[
\langle\Omega,\pi(a)\Omega\rangle=\langle [1],[a]\rangle=S(1^*\theta(a))=S(\theta(a))=S(a),
\]
using $S\circ\theta=S$ from (S). For $a\in\theta(\mathfrak A_+)$, write $a=\theta(b)$ and compute
\[
\langle\Omega,\pi(\theta(b))\Omega\rangle=\langle\Omega,J\pi(b^*)J\Omega\rangle=\langle J\Omega,\pi(b^*)J\Omega\rangle
=\langle [1],[b]\rangle=S(\theta(b))=S(a).
\]
By linearity and multiplicativity, \eqref{eq:vac} holds on $\mathrm{alg}(\mathfrak A_+,\theta(\mathfrak A_+))$.


\emph{Step 4 (Euclidean time‑evolution on $\mathcal H$).} Define $U(t)$ for $t\ge 0$ on the dense subspace $\mathfrak A_+/\mathcal N$ by
\[
U(t)[a]:=[\tau_t(a)],\qquad a\in\mathfrak A_+.
\]
\underline{Well‑definedness:} If $[a]=0$ then $S(a^*\theta(a))=0$. Consider in the larger GNS space of the state $S$ (axiom (S)) the unitary $V(t)$ implementing $\tau_t$ and the antiunitary $\Theta$ implementing $\theta$; then $\langle \Lambda(a),\Theta\Lambda(a)\rangle=S(a^*\theta(a))=0$ implies
\[
\langle V(t)\Lambda(a),\Theta V(t)\Lambda(a)\rangle
=\langle \Lambda(a),V(-t)\Theta V(t)\Lambda(a)\rangle
=\langle \Lambda(a),\Theta\Lambda(a)\rangle=0,
\]
because $\Theta V(t)\Theta=V(-t)$ by $\theta\tau_t\theta=\tau_{-t}$. Hence $[\tau_t(a)]=0$. Thus $U(t)$ is well‑defined on the quotient.


\underline{Contraction and symmetry:} For $[a]\in\mathfrak A_+$,
\[
\|U(t)[a]\|^2=S\big( (\tau_t a)^*\,\theta(\tau_t a)\big)=S\big(a^*\tau_{-2t}(\theta a)\big).
\]
Define $f(\lambda):=S\big(a^*\tau_{-\lambda}(\theta a)\big)$ for $\lambda\ge 0$. OS positivity plus $\tau$‑invariance makes $\lambda\mapsto f(\lambda)$ a positive‑definite function on $\mathbb R$ (check the $2\times2$ matrix at times $0$ and $\lambda$). Hence $|f(\lambda)|\le f(0)$ for all $\lambda$. Taking $\lambda=2t$ yields
\[
\|U(t)[a]\|^2=f(2t)\le f(0)=\|[a]\|^2,
\]
so $\|U(t)\|\le 1$. Moreover, for $a,b\in\mathfrak A_+$,
\[
\langle U(t)[a],[b]\rangle=S\big((\tau_t a)^*\theta(b)\big)
=S\big(a^*\tau_{-t}(\theta b)\big)=S\big(a^*\theta(\tau_t b)\big)=\langle [a],U(t)[b]\rangle,
\]
so each $U(t)$ is symmetric. Being bounded and symmetric on all of $\mathcal H$, $U(t)$ is (bounded) self‑adjoint.


\underline{Semigroup and strong continuity:} $U(t+s)[a]=[\tau_{t+s}a]=U(t)U(s)[a]$. By (C), $t\mapsto U(t)[a]=[\tau_t a]$ is continuous for each $[a]$ in the dense core, hence $U(t)$ is a strongly continuous contraction semigroup.


By the spectral theorem for strongly continuous self‑adjoint contraction semigroups, there is a unique non‑negative self‑adjoint generator $H\ge 0$ with
\[
U(t)=e^{-tH},\qquad t\ge 0.
\]
Equivalently, with $T:=U(1)$ positive self‑adjoint and $\|T\|\le 1$, one may set $H:=-\log T$ by functional calculus; then $U(t)=e^{-tH}$ for all $t\ge 0$.


\underline{Covariance:} For $a\in\mathfrak A_+$ and $[b]\in\mathcal H$,
\[
U(t)\pi(a)[b]=U(t)[ab]=[\tau_t(a)\,\tau_t(b)]=\pi(\tau_t a)U(t)[b],
\]
so $U(t)\pi(a)=\pi(\tau_t a)U(t)$ on $\mathfrak A_+$. For $x\in\theta(\mathfrak A_+)$, use $\pi(\theta a)=J\pi(a^*)J$ and $J U(t) J=U(t)$ (from symmetry and $\theta\tau_t\theta=\tau_{-t}$) to extend \eqref{eq:cov} to $\mathrm{alg}(\mathfrak A_+,\theta(\mathfrak A_+))$. If, in addition, $\{\tau_t\}_{t\in\mathbb R}$ acts by automorphisms on the whole algebra, then the semigroup integrates to the unitary real‑time group $e^{isH}$ and the usual conjugation formula $\pi(\tau_t x)=e^{-tH}\pi(x)e^{tH}$ holds on the natural domain.


\emph{Step 5 (spectral gap transfer).} Let $T:=U(1)=e^{-H}$.
Assume $\mathrm{spec}\!\left(T\!\restriction_{\Omega^\perp}\right)\subset[0,e^{-\gamma}]$ for some $\gamma>0$
(the constant sector is $\mathbb C\Omega$, where $T\Omega=\Omega$ and $H\Omega=0$).
By spectral calculus, on $\Omega^\perp$ the spectrum of $H=-\log T$ is
\[
\mathrm{spec}\!\left(H\!\restriction_{\Omega^\perp}\right)=\{-\log\lambda:\ \lambda\in \mathrm{spec}\!\left(T\!\restriction_{\Omega^\perp}\right)\}\subset [\gamma,\infty).
\]
Hence $\mathrm{spec}(H)\cap(0,\gamma)=\varnothing$, as claimed.


\paragraph{Remarks.}
\begin{itemize}
\item The operators $U(t)=e^{-tH}$ are \emph{self‑adjoint contractions} (Euclidean time). The \emph{unitary} real‑time group is $e^{isH}$, $s\in\mathbb R$. If one insists on writing a conjugation identity with $U(\pm t)$, interpret $U(-t)$ as $e^{tH}$ on the natural domain (unbounded for $t>0$).
\item The role of ``loops'' is to specify the observable algebra; the reconstruction above depends only on (RP),(TT),(S),(OS),(C).
\end{itemize}
